Thanks for following our live coverage. It has now ended:

Here's a summary of what happened in New York last night: 

There was no defeat to be snatched from the jaws of victory.

The man who shockingly secured the Democratic nomination in June has un-shockingly won the election. Zohran Mamdani, the dimpled, wise-cracking democratic socialist, will become mayor of New York, America's most populous city.

For those with a taste for 11th-hour upsets in politics, there was little reason to anticipate a surprise. The Mamdani campaign carried the momentum from its primary battle, drawing the highest turnout in a New York mayoral race since the 1960s.

A highly-energised coalition of young white Leftists and new immigrant communities disrupted the traditional New York Dem voting blocs. In the end, it wasn't even remotely close.

It will be hard to resist the urge to see the result as a stunning endorsement of Mamdani's particular flavour of progressivism, bolstered by further blows against the GOP in New Jersey and Virginia.

Zohran Mamdani, a pro-Palestinian socialist, has been elected the first Muslim mayor of New York City.

The Left-wing politician, 34, beat Andrew Cuomo, the former governor of New York, and Curtis Sliwa, the Republican candidate, in the dramatic race.

His historic win marked the end of an extraordinary election in which Mr Mamdani was propelled from fringe candidate to frontrunner through a slick social media campaign centred on affordability in one of the world's most expensive cities.

Mr Mamdani tapped into residents' frustrations with skyrocketing living costs by pegging his campaign to sweeping promises of free buses, free childcare and city-run supermarkets.

The 34-year-old, who will become the city's youngest mayor in more than 100 years, also vowed to freeze rent in rent-controlled properties and raise funds for his ambitious pledges by increasing taxes for the city's highest earners.

Donald Trump issued an ominous warning to Zohran Mamdani after the democratic socialist swept to victory in New York's mayoral election, writing: “And so it begins…”

Mr Trump posted the brief message on Truth Social midway through Mr Mamdani's mayoral victory speech, which had included several jabs at the US president.

The post could be seen as Mr Trump firing the starting gun on the campaign for the 2026 mid-term elections. Republicans have signalled they intend use Mr Mamdani as a symbol of Left-wing radicalism as a weapon against the Democrats.

Mr Trump, who has said he plans to stop Mr Mamdani “destroying” New York and floated withholding federal funds from the city, could also be hinting at an epic clash between his administration and the new mayor.

The US president has recently sent federal troops into several US cities, but has so far avoided stamping his authority on New York.

The US government shutdown has officially become the longest in history, beating the previous record of 35 days.

On Tuesday night, US president Donald Trump claimed Democrat successes in a series of elections were a result of the shutdown, alongside the fact that he was not on the ballot.

He renewed his call for Senate Republicans to ditch the filibuster to reopen the government and force through his legislative priorities. 

John Thune, the GOP Senate leader, has said he does not intend to go ahead with the president's plan.

Zohran Mamdani's victory as a democratic socialist in New York City is an odd one as analysts try to tease out lessons for next year's midterm elections and forecast who will end up controlling Congress.

“It's a weird situation,” said pollster James Johnson, who pointed out that Mr Mamdani' main challenger was Andrew Cuomo, a former Democrat running as an independent. “It's not Republican versus Democrat, so I don't think we can learn anything from that.”

Yet the stunning victory will have delighted two sets of political campaigners: Mr Mamdani's supporters and Republican strategists around the country.

The National Republican Congressional Committee, for example, immediately set out its plan for the midterms and the way it would tie Democratic candidates to Mr Mamdani's radical politics.

“Every House Democrat is foolishly complicit in their party's collapse, and voters will make them pay in 2026,” said spokesman Mike Marinella.

“…AND SO IT BEGINS!” Donald Trump wrote on his Truth Social platform, seemingly responding to Zohran Mamdani's victory speech, in which he was called out several times.

Mr Mamdani's speech has now concluded.

“Hear me, President Trump, when I say this. To get to any of us, you will have to get through all of us,” Zohran Mamdani says, virtually shouting over the cheers of supporters.

“The conventional wisdom would tell you that I am far from the perfect candidate,” Mr Mamdani says, noting he is young, Muslim, a Democratic socialist and “most damning of all, I refuse to apologise for any of this”.

He adds: “No longer will we have to open a history book for proof that Democrats can dare to be great.”

“We will prove that there is no problem too large for government to solve and no concern too small for it to care about,” Zohran Mamdani says.

“If anyone can show a nation betrayed by Donald Trump how to defeat him, it is the city that gave rise to him,” the Democrat continues.

“If there is any way to terrify a despot, it is by dismantling the very conditions that allowed him to accumulate power.

“So Donald Trump, since I know you're watching, I have four words for you: turn the volume up.”

“Billionaires like Trump” have been able to “evade taxation and exploit tax breaks” because of a “culture of corruption”, he claims.

Politics is “no longer... something that is done to us”, Zohran Mamdani claims. “Now it is something that we do.”

“Tonight we have have stepped out from the old into the new. So let us speak now with clarity and conviction that cannot be misunderstood,” he says.

“This will be an age where New Yorkers expect from their leaders a bold vision of what we will achieve rather than a list of excuses,” Mr Mamdani continues.

He pledges to introduce an “ambitious agenda to tackle the cost of living”, to “freeze the rents for more than two million rent-stabilised tenants, make buses fast and free, and deliver universal childcare across our city”.

Mr Mamdani continues: “In this moment of political darkness, New York will be the light... whether you are an immigrant, a member of the trans community, one of the many black women that Donald Trump has fired from a federal job.”

“We will build a city hall that stands steadfast alongside Jewish New Yorkers and does not waver in the fight against the scourge of anti-Semitism,” he pledges.

Citing the example of a New Yorker forced to commute into the city from Pennsylvania, Zohran Mamdani declares: “Rent is too expensive in this city.”

Cost of living, and in particular the spiralling cost of rent, were a key theme of the Democrat's campaign.

“Because of you we will make this city one that working people can love and live in again,” he says.

Mr Mamdani says he has “one final request”: “New York City, breathe this moment in. We have held our breath for longer than we know. We have held it in anticipation of defeat, held it because the air has been knocked out of our lungs too many times to count.

“Thanks to all of those who sacrificed so much, we are breathing in the air of a city that has been reborn.”

He tells his parents they have “made me into the man I am today”, adding: “I am so proud to be your son.”

“Thank you to the next generation of New Yorkers who refused to accept that the promise of a better future was a relic of the past,” Zohran Mamdani says.

“You showed that when politics speaks to you without condescension, we can usher in a new era of leadership.”

Zohran Mamdani is delivering his victory speech now.

“The sun may have set over city this evening but as Eugene Debbs once said, ‘I can see the dawn of a better day for humanity,” the future New York mayor begins.

“For as long as we can remember the working people of New York have been told by the wealthy and the well-connected that the power does not belong in their hands... and yet over the last 12 months, you have dared to reach for something greater.

“Tonight, against all odds, we have grasped it. The future is in our hands. My friends, we have toppled a political dynasty,” he says, referring to his defeat of Andrew Cuomo, son of former New York governor Mario Cuomo.

“I wish Andrew Cuomo only the best in private life. But let tonight be the last time I utter his name.”

Chuck Schumer has congratulated Zohran Mamdani on his win tonight despite refusing to endorse the socialist.

“His campaign was relentlessly focused on the cost-of-living crisis, that Donald Trump has only made worse,” the Democrat Senate leader said, taking the opportunity to hit out at the US president.

Mr Schumer continued: “I have worked collaboratively and productively with mayor-elect Mamdani on a number of vital issues over the years - including delivering historic relief to our taxi drivers who were suffering under crushing and unfair debt.

“I look forward to building on that partnership to keep New York City strong, fair, more affordable, and thriving.”

Eric Adams, the New York mayor, has pledged to protect communities who opposed Zohran Mamdani, in what appears to be a message aimed at Jewish voters.

A CNN exit poll released soon after polls closed this evening found 60 per cent of Jewish voters voted for Andrew Cuomo compared to 31 per cent for Zohran Mamdani, who nevertheless went on to win the mayoral election.

Mr Adams, who leaves office in January, offered his congratulations to his successor before seemingly addressing the city's Jewish population.

Our shared mission must always be to put New York City first and build a safer, more affordable city that is the best place to raise a family.A message to my fellow New Yorkers. pic.twitter.com/OkicJAcqNN

“To all those communities who voted for someone else, we understand your concerns, we understand your fears, we understand the anxiety you are feeling. But this is our democracy,” he said.

Mr Adams continued: “As your former mayor and as a former member of the New York City police department, I will be committed to ensure your safety and your acceptance in the city that we all love.”

Gavin Newsom's plan to redistrict California and net Democrats five extra seats in the House of Representatives has been approved by the state's voters, according to projections.

Andrew Cuomo has hailed Zohran Mamdani as the future of the Democrats in his concession speech.

“This campaign was to contest the philosophies that are shaping the Democratic party, the future of this city and the future of this country,” he said.

Mr Mamdani, a 34-year-old socialist, ran a campaign focused on the cost of living, while Mr Cuomo, the 67-year-old former New York governor, stuck more to the centre ground.

New Yorkers “will not tolerate any behaviour that fans the flames of anti-Semitism,” he warns.

When his supporters boo the mention of Mr Mamdani's name, Mr Cuomo admonishes them. “That is not right... tonight was their night,” he says.

Sadiq Khan, the London mayor, has passed on his “huge congratulations” to Zohran Mamdani following his mayoral election win.

“New Yorkers faced a clear choice - between hope and fear - and just like we've seen in London - hope won,” Mr Khan wrote on social media.

“Huge congratulations to [Zohran Mamdani] on his historic campaign.”

Mr Mamdani will be the first Muslim mayor of New York when he takes office in January. Mr Khan became the first Muslim mayor of London when he was elected in May 2016.

New Yorkers faced a clear choice - between hope and fear - and just like we've seen in London - hope won.Huge congratulations to @ZohranKMamdani on his historic campaign.

Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez has urged fellow Democrats not to be “afraid of the future” after Zohran Mamdani's mayoral win in New York.

“We don't have to be afraid of the future and we don't have to be afraid of our young,” she said, urging Democrats to “lean into the promise of our party.”

“It's not just a message about Democrats,” she added, saying voters were “appalled by the cowardice of Congress” and labelling US president Donald Trump a “handmaiden to billionaires”.

Barack Obama has said Democrats still have “plenty of work to do” despite a series of high-profile wins tonight.

“When we come together around strong, forward-looking leaders who care about the issues that matter, we can win,” the former US president wrote on social media.

“We've got still got plenty of work to do, but the future looks a little bit brighter.”

Congratulations to all the Democratic candidates who won tonight. It's a reminder that when we come together around strong, forward-looking leaders who care about the issues that matter, we can win. We've still got plenty of work to do, but the future looks a little bit brighter.

Abigail Spanberger has been urged to “consider all of us Virginians” by her defeated Republican opponent.

Winsome Earle-Sears said she had called the Democrat, who did not answer, and wished her success in a voicemail message instead.

“I asked her to please consider all of us Virginians, that she will represent all of us, not just some us,” said Ms Earle-Sears, the state's lieutenant governor.

“And I wished her success. If she is successful, Virginia will be successful. That's what I wish for.”

Jay Jones, the Democrat candidate who mused about murdering Republicans in leaked texts, has won a close race for Virginia attorney general. 

The race has been called for Mr Jones by the Associated Press, several hours after Abigail Spanberger's win in the gubernatorial election in the same state.

Donald Trump has claimed that Republican losses tonight are because he wasn't on the ballot and the ongoing government shutdown.

“TRUMP WASN'T ON THE BALLOT, AND SHUTDOWN, WERE THE TWO REASONS THAT REPUBLICANS LOST ELECTIONS TONIGHT,” according to Pollsters,” the US president wrote on Truth Social.

Chuck Schumer, the Democrat leader in the Senate, has called the flurry of Democrat wins a “repudiation of the Trump agenda”.

“The cruelty, chaos and greed that define Maga radicalism and are skyrocketing costs were firmly rejected by the American people,” he said in a statement earlier this evening.

“If Republicans want to keep blindly following Donald Trump into the abyss of chaos, let them. The rest of America is moving forward.”

Mikie Sherrill tells supporters in New Jersey: “I am in incredibly honoured to be your next governor.”

“I know how hard it can be to serve in these times and I just got a call from [Republican rival] Jack Ciattarelli, and I want to recognise him for stepping up,” she says.

This is greeted with both applause and jeers from the crowd.

Ms Sherrill says Donald Trump is “backing away” from democratic ideals, and vows: “We here in New Jersey are here to fight for a different future for our children.”

She continues: We know that no one in our great state is safe when our neighbours are targeted, ignoring the law and the Constitution... governors have never mattered more.”

Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez, the Left-wing New York congresswoman, is celebrating at Zohran Mamdani's watch party after the socialist's commanding mayoral election win.

Ms Ocasio-Cortez has been a key supporter of Mr Mamdani, and appeared with him alongside the former presidential candidate Bernie Sanders to rally progressive voters a week before the election.

Zohran Mamdani has been urged to “stand unequivocally against anti-Semitism” by the US' largest Jewish civil rights group.

The Anti-Defamation League said the future New York mayor had a “long, disturbing record on issues of deep concern to the Jewish community”, and vowed to “ensure the safety and security of all Jewish New Yorkers”.

“We will neither compromise nor relent in our pursuit of our core purpose, to protect the Jewish people,” it added.

Mikie Sherrill has said it is “the honour of my life” to win the election for New Jersey governor.

“I promise to listen, lead with courage, and never forget who I serve,” she said in a statement on social media.

New Jersey, it is the honor of my life to earn your trust to become this great state's 57th Governor. I promise to listen, lead with courage, and never forget who I serve. pic.twitter.com/gipM0fWnqF

Brooklyn Paramount erupted into screams of elation as AP called the race for Zohran Mamdani.

There are chants of “Zohran, Zohran, Zohran” as Lean Back by Terror Squad blasts through the speakers.

I was speaking to tenant organiser Lex Rountree as the election was called, who burst into tears.

“I am beyond thrilled,” she screamed, tears streaming down her face.

Zohran Mamdani, the winner of New York's mayoral election, has posted a video on social media of a subway door opening at a stop that reads: City Hall.

pic.twitter.com/cpPF3SPl5g

Cheers rang out across Zohran Mamdani's watch party in Brooklyn when the Democrat was widely projected to have become the first Muslim mayor of New York.

Mr Mamdani, who was considered a long-shot candidate when he entered the Democratic primaries earlier this year, was projected to have won the race by major news outlets within minutes of ballots closing on Tuesday.

Zohran Mamdani volunteer Allegra Rosenbaum says she hopes the young politician's success will translate to Democrats and socialists being elected across the country.

“I think there's a pink tide coming,” the 33-year-old, who works in marketing, told The Telegraph.

“When Trump got elected I was really scared, but what Zohran did is he captured the political moment and he reversed it.

“He gave everyone in New York, well, almost everyone in New York, a lot of hope and I think that's something really special.

Zohran Mamdani has won the New York mayoral race, according to multiple projections, becoming the first Muslim mayor of the city. The Associated Press, NBC News, Decision Desk HQ, CNN and Fox News have all called the race for the Democrat.

Democrat Mikie Sherrill is projected to have won the New Jersey governor's race.

US president Donald Trump had made a number of appeals on behalf of the Republican candidate, Jack Ciattarelli, but his intervention seems not to have been enough to turn the tide in The Garden State.

New York has seen its highest turnout in a mayoral race in almost 60 years, with more than two million voters casting a ballot.

The last time it passed that threshold, according to city authorities, was 1969: a few months after Neil Armstrong and Buzz Aldrin became the first men to walk on the Moon.

Just over a million votes have been counted so far. Currently, Zohran Mamdani has a lead of around eight points over Andrew Cuomo.

Zohran Mamdani's team are being tightlipped about plans for tonight, but they have given away one detail: tonight is a celebration.

Two members of his team buoyantly told me to have fun.

“It's a party”, one said, adding that they have booked the venue until 1am.

Republicans are starting to get their caveats in on the Virginia governor's race, arguing that it would be unwise to draw sweeping conclusions from their loss.

Chris LaCivita, one of the masterminds behind Donald Trump's 2024 presidential win, said blame the candidate and the campaign.

A Bad candidate and Bad campaign have consequences - the Virginia Governors race is example number 1.

It's worth noting that when Mr Trump held a tele-rally for Winsome Earle-Sears a day before the election, he did not even mention the Republican candidate by name.

Decision Desk HQ has projected Zohran Mamdani to win New York's mayoral election race, within minutes of polls closing.

Other news outlets have yet to call the race. So far, Mr Mamdani has an 11.2 per cent lead over Andrew Cuomo, his nearest rival, with 38 per cent of the votes counted.

Hasan Piker, the twitch streamer who once said America “deserved 9/11” is at Zohran Mamdani's watch party.

There is a gaggle of press surrounding him and hundreds of members of the press mill around the cavernous music venue.

Andrew Cuomo and Mr Mamdani's opponents have frequently attacked the socialist for appearing with Mr Piker during the Democratic primary.

Mr Mamdani said he found Mr Piker's 2019 comments “objectionable and reprehensible.”

Economic worries topped voter concerns at the ballot box, according to early results from the Associated Press Voter Poll.

It asked 17,000 voters in New Jersey, Virginia, California and New York City for the issues that decided their vote, such as security and the overall direction of the country.

But a year after Mr Trump won the White House by promising to bring prices under control and unleash growth, it suggests that he has not done enough to reassure voters that a cost of living crisis is easing.

Although the stock market remains healthy, hiring is slowing and inflation is almost a full percentage point above its two per cent target.

Add to that a federal shutdown, as Congress remains deadlocked over budget measures, and the economy remains the top worry for voters. In Virginia, for example, half of voters said it was there number one concern.

That could be a major problem for Republicans next year. They control the White House and both chambers of Congress, making it hard for them to say the economy is not their fault.

Zohran Mamdani has taken a commanding lead in New York with a little over a third of the votes tallied. Mr Mamdani has 51.5 per cent of votes, compared to 39.7 per cent for Andrew Cuomo and 8 per cent for Curtis Sliwa.

A CNN exit poll shows Mr Cuomo leads Mr Mamdani among Jewish voters by 60 per cent to 31 per cent.

Polls have now closed in the New York mayoral race. Zohran Mamdani, the socialist Democrat candidate, is considered a heavy favourite and according to CNN is “putting the final touches” to his victory speech.

Cory Bowman, half-brother of US vice president JD Vance, has lost his race for Cincinnati mayor to Democrat Aftab Pureval, according to projections.

Mr Vance had previously endorsed Mr Bowman ahead of the Republican primary in May, calling him a “good guy with a heart for serving his community”.

Jay Jones, the Democrats' candidate for attorney general in Virginia who mused about shooting Republicans in leaked text messages, is projected to have won the race by Decision Desk HQ. Other major news outlets have not yet to made a call.

Mikie Sherrill has been projected to win the New Jersey governor's race by Decision Desk HQ, which would be a key Democrat win in a state where the Republicans were thought to have a fighting chance. Other major news outlets, such as the Associated Press, are yet to make a call.

“We can unite for Virginia's future, and we can set an example for the rest of the nation,” Abigail Spanberger continues.

That comment could have be aimed at US president Donald Trump. But it could also have been an appeal to her party to embrace her centrist politics rather than those of Zohran Mamdani, the socialist New York mayoral candidate who is widely expected to win tonight.

Abigail Spanberger has appeared to address supporters after her projected win in Virginia, walking out to Florence and the Machine's “Dog Days Are Over”.

“Tonight we sent a message,” she tells the crowd, who roar their approval.

“We sent a message to every corner of the Commonwealth, a message to our neighbours and our fellow Americans across the country. We sent a message to the whole world that in 2025 Virginia chose pragmatism over partisanship.

“We chose our Commonwealth over chaos. You all chose leadership that will focus relentlessly on what matters most: lowering costs, keeping our communities is safe and strengthening our economy for every Virginian.

“Leadership that will focus on problem solving, not stoking division.”

Ms Spanberger declares she “cannot wait to get to work for you”, saying they have “turned a page... [by] focusing on practical results, playing out a clear agenda.”

We are a long way yet from getting the full voter results that will show exactly how Abigail Spanberger won the Virginia governor's race. But there are a few early conclusions we can draw.

First, her win came as no surprise. Virginia voters like to elect governors from a different party to the White House. And she managed to keep Democrats on board with appeals to abortion rights while winning over Republican voters with a moderate economic message.

Second, it shows that in purple states, such as Virginia, there is a lane for moderates to win from the center. Ms Spanberger is a former CIA case officer who, as a Member of Congress, railed against her party's focus on identity politics. She is not one of the loudmouthed progressives who seem to dominate the headlines and fundraising and chatter.

How much this matters we will find out later when we get the results from New York City, where Zohran Mamdani is very much not a Democrat in the Spanberger mould.

Maybe his radical zeal and energy in turning out young voters gives Democrats a shot in the arm. But Ms Spanberger's win shows there is also a place for fighting from the centre.

Ghazala Hashmi is widely projected to have won the election for Virginia's lieutenant governor, the second Democrat success in the state after Abigail Spanberger's win earlier in the night.

Gavin Newsom has congratulated Abigail Spanberger on becoming the first female governor of Virginia and flipping the state to the Democrats.

The California governor wrote on social media: “What an incredible win!!! Congratulations to the new Governor-elect.”

What an incredible win!!! Congratulations to the new Governor-elect @SpanbergerForVA! https://t.co/2DKfylXb0k

 

Andrew Cuomo's election night watch party in Manhattan is largely empty, according to The New York Times. Reporters and a handful of supporters are so far the only ones present.

Polls in the mayoral race close in 40 minutes.

By contrast, at Zohran Mamdani's watch party, where The Telegraph is reporting, hundreds of journalists are queueing outside the Brooklyn Paramount.

Democrat Mikie Sherill has taken an early lead in New Jersey, leading Jack Ciattarelli 54.4 per cent to 45 per cent with 12 per cent of the votes tallied.

The two independent candidates, Vic Kaplan and Joanna Kuniansky, have just 0.5 per cent of the vote between them so far.

Polls have now closed in New Jersey. The race for governor between Mikie Sherrill and Jack Ciattarelli is expected to be significantly closer than in Virginia, where Democrat Abigail Spanberger is widely projected to have beaten Winsome Earle-Sears.

Polls have closed, and no matter the result tonight, I'm filled with gratitude.This campaign has been a love letter to you, New Jersey. Thank you for sharing your dreams and fears, and thank you especially to everyone who chipped in, volunteered, and trusted me with their vote.

Abigail Spanberger has been projected to win the Virginia governor's race by several US news outlets including NBC News, CNN and the Associated Press, flipping control from the Republicans to the Democrats.

By contrast, the race for attorney general is neck-and-neck. Democrat Jay Jones, whose campaign was badly rocked by leaked text messages, is under a percentage point ahead of his rival, Jason Miyares, with almost a third of votes tallied.

I'm outside Brooklyn Paramount with the rest of the world's media queueing to get into Zohran Mamdani's watch party.

There are hundreds of journalists here - the line snakes round the block. I haven't seen so many reporters gathered in this city since Donald Trump was in court.

The likes of Duke Ellington and Ella Fitzgerald once performed in the baroque-style former cinema, but tonight the venue will be packed with supporters hoping to see another star.

While the Mamdani campaign has booked an iconic venue which usually draws music fans from the five boroughs and beyond (Led Zeppelin's Robert Plant is lighting up the stage tomorrow), Andrew Cuomo's team has been notably quiet.

His spokesman previously told The Telegraph details for his watch party would be released this week, but nothing has been sent out, suggesting the former New York governor does not have big plans to celebrate this evening.

Curtis Sliwa, the Republican candidate, has booked out Arte Cafe, an Italian restaurant on the Upper West Side.

Abigail Spanberger is maintaining her lead over Winsome Earle-Sears with roughly a fifth of the vote in. She leads the Republican 57.7 per cent to 42.1 per cent, a margin of more than 100,000 votes.

Abigail Spanberger has taken an early lead as votes are tallied in Virginia governor's race. With around 10,000 votes tallied, she has taken 62.3 per cent to Winsome Earle-Sears' 37.6 per cent.

Only a tiny proportion of votes have been tallied so far, and the race is considered too early to call for either candidate.

Jay Jones, the Democrat whose campaign for Virginia attorney general was rocked by leaked texts in which he spoke about murdering Republicans, leads his rival Jason Miyares by a smaller margin: 53 per cent to 46.6 per cent.

Polls are now closed in Virginia.

Polls in Virginia are due to close within minutes. Polls in New Jersey will close in slightly over an hour, at 8pm EST.

Turnout in New York's mayoral election has hit 1.85 million, according to reports. That means more people have voted in the current race than in 2001, which took place just months after 9/11.

Donald Trump has issued a last-minute appeal for voters to turn out for Jack Ciattarelli, the Republican candidate for governor in New Jersey.

“I just heard that 32,000 Orthodox Jews around Lakewood and Jackson, New Jersey, have showed up BIG for Jack Ciattarelli” the US president wrote on his Truth Social platform. 

“My friends in this Great Community know how important this Election is to New Jersey, and to our Country. There is still time to vote!

The New Jersey's governor race is considered one of the closest contests taking place tonight. Polling has given Democrat Mikie Sherrill a small advantage over Mr Ciattarelli.

Polls in Virginia close in one hour, at 7pm EST. Abigail Spanberger, the Democrat candidate for governor, is considered a heavy favourite in the gubernatorial race.

Eric Adams, New York's outgoing mayor, has cast his vote for Andrew Cuomo.

“My vote is clearly for Governor Cuomo. We can't go backwards. This city's not a socialist city,” Mr Adams said, hitting out at Zohran Mamdani, who is odds-on to win tonight.

The mayor added: “The only message I can give to New Yorkers as I go to the next leg of my journey: I'm leaving you a good city... Don't mess it up.”

Zohran Mamdani stood on stage basking in his victory.

Dressed in a trademark black suit, surrounded by his security detail, he vowed not to abandon the young voters who had helped him.

He had won against all the odds, mopping the floor with his establishment rivals.

No, this is not 2025. This is 2004, when Mr Mamdani, the rookie, viral socialist mayoral candidate now on the brink of a revolutionary mayoral victory in New York, was just 12 years old.

Voter turnout in the New York mayoral race is at its highest level since the aftermath of 9/11.

More than 1.45 million ballots have so far been cast in the city, where polls are open until 9pm EST.

Some 1.52 million people voted in 2001, which took place two months after thousands were killed in the 9/11 attacks.

That year, with incumbent Rudy Giuliani unable to run given term limits, Republican Mike Bloomberg defeated Democrat Mark Green in a close contest.

Chuck Schumer, the Democrat leader in the Senate, declined to say whether he voted for Zohran Mamdani in the New York mayoral election.

Mr Schumer, a senator for New York, was asked whether he had cast a ballot for Mr Mamdani, the Democrat candidate whom he has refused to endorse, or Andrew Cuomo, who is running as an independent.

“Look, I voted and I look forward to working with the next mayor to help New York City,” Mr Schumer responded.

Hakeem Jeffries, the Democrat leader in the House of Representatives and a New York congressman, held off endorsing Mr Mamdani until two weeks ago.

A Republican attorney general candidate in Virginia seems to have acknowledged his party will lose the state's gubernatorial race.

Jason Miyares has encouraged voters supporting Abigail Spanberger, the Democrat candidate for governor, to back his bid for attorney general.

“Dave's splitting his ticket - you can too,” Mr Miyares wrote on social media.

Ms Spanberger is considered a heavy favourite in the race, so much so that US president Donald Trump has not endorsed her Republican opponent, Winsome Earle-Seares.

By contrast, the attorney general contest is considered a toss-up after leaked texts from Jay Jones, Mr Miyares' opponent, showed the Democrat talking about murdering Republicans.

Zohran Mamdani isn't the “future” of the Democrats, Pennsylvanian senator John Fetterman has said.

Mr Fetterman was asked by Fox News about how Democrat voters should see the rise of prominent Left-wingers such as Mr Mamdani or Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez, the New York congresswoman.

“Socialism isn't my party's future, certainly not,” he told Fox News.

Mr Mamdani would be a “voice from New York City”, which is very Left-wing and “not really relevant” to the rest of the country, he said.

Mr Fetterman continued: “If Mamdani wins, I don't think he's going to be campaigning in all of the ... kinds of states that are going to determine... who's going to be the next president.”

Zohran Mamdani has attacked Andrew Cuomo for being endorsed by Donald Trump on the campaign trail, hours before polls close.

The endorsement “makes explicit what has been implicit for many months,” he told NBC News.

“Throughout the course of the primary, there were many of us who raised concerns about the fact that the former governor was running a campaign funded in large part by the same billionaire donors who had funded Donald Trump's campaign.”

It means Mr Cuomo, whose campaign has said he is the best candidate to stand up to Mr Trump, would be “too busy cashing cheques for his donors” to defy the president, he claimed.

Kentucky authorities have warned constituents they cannot vote in New York's mayoral race after being inundated with calls.

“We're getting calls about polls being closed. They are closed because we do not have elections today,” Kentucky Secretary of State Michael Adams wrote on X.

Kentuckians are next due to go to the polls in 2026, when they will elect a candidate to replace retiring Republican senator Mitch McConnell. They will vote on state officials again in 2027.

Mr Adams added: “Kentucky votes next year. You cannot vote today in Kentucky for the mayor of New York City or the Governor of Virginia. Sorry.”

In Minneapolis, Democratic Mayor Jacob Frey is seeking to fend off a democratic socialist challenge in a crowded race.

Mr Frey faces a steep challenge in today's election in a race that highlights different visions of how to govern in a liberal city confronting persistent problems with policing, crime and homelessness.

The incumbent, who is seeking a third term, is under fire from Left-win state senator Omar Fateh, who hopes to become the city's first Muslim and Somali American mayor.

Fateh has drawn comparisons with Zohran Mamdani, because of their shared faith and ideological similarities. Both come from immigrant families, although Fateh, a member of the city's large Somali American community, was born in the US.

Read our full profile of the “Minneapolis Mamdani” here.

The White House is considering signing an executive order to crack down on voter fraud.

Karoline Leavitt, the White House press secretary, said the Trump administration is working on an order to root out the practice following claims of “blatant fraud” in California.

Ms Leavitt said: “It's absolutely true that there [is] fraud in...California's elections. It's just a fact. It is just a fact. They have a universal mail-in voting system, which we know is ripe for fraud.”

She added that there are “countless examples” of fraudulent ballots being mailed in under the names of “illegal aliens who shouldn't be voting in American elections”.

Taking to Truth Social earlier today, Donald Trump claimed without evidence that voting in the state's redistricting battle is “rigged” because mail-in ballots are leading to Republicans being “shut out”.

The White House has accused Zohran Mamdani of behaving “irresponsibly” after he accused Donald Trump of “trying to intimidate voters with baseless allegations of voter fraud”.

Responding to Mr Mamdani's comments, Karoline Leavitt, the White House press secretary said the New York mayoral candidate's comments were “completely irresponsible” and are “based on zero evidence”.

“I think they are completely irresponsible and they are based on zero evidence, and I think this is just another example of how the Democrat Party unfortunately stands for nothing,” Ms Leavitt said. “All they stand against is President Donald Trump, and I think it's quite sad to see that we have someone at the top of the ticket on an election day today saying such things about the President.”

The Democrats have signalled confidence as election day unfolds across gubernatorial races in New Jersey and Virginia and the mayoral race in New York City.

“We're confident, but we're not complacent,” Ken Martin, the chair of the Democratic National Committee (DNC) told CNN. “We're going to keep our foot on the gas and do everything we can in the remaining hours here to turn out as many votes as we can.”

Mr Martin said that the Democrats' focus on affordability across all three races will serve as a blueprint for the party as it looks ahead to next year's midterm elections.

“When we focus on an economic message right, and we focus on those kitchen table issues, we can win,” he told the news outlet. “It's when we get distracted or pulled into other issues that we start to lose connection with the electorate.”

However, he stopped short of suggesting that the part should model itself exclusively on the model of democratic-socialist Zohran Mamdani, whose meteoric rise has delighted the progressive wing of his party and sowed concern among centrists.

“It takes different types of candidates to win in different parts of the country,” Mr Martin said. “The goal is to find candidates who fit those districts and run them.

“There's no one way or one stripe to be a Democrat.”

Alex Soros, the Left-wing billionaire, has voted for Zohran Mamdani.

The philanthropist and investor, whose family is a frequent target of Republican attacks owing to their support for progressive political campaigns, said he is “proud” to cast his ballot for Mr Mamdani.

“I was proud to support and vote for the Democratic candidate for mayor,” Mr Soros wrote in an email to The New York Times.

New York may be on course for record voter turnout in the Mayoral election.

More people have already voted in this year's election than in the entire 2021 race, with eight hours to go until polls close.

Nearly 460,000 New Yorkers had cast their ballot by noon on election day, while 735,000 people voted early, bringing the current total to around 1.2 million votes. In 2021, when Eric Adams won, just 1.15 million people voted.

Voter enthusiasm may partly be attributed to Zohran Mamdani's ability to galvanise young voters, who made up more than half of early voters, reversing a previous trend in which early voting was dominated by Gen X and Boomers.

The record for voter turnout in a New York mayoral race was set in 1989, when nearly 1.9 million citizens cast their ballot in the race that saw Democratic candidate David Dinkins defeat Republican Rudy Giuliani.

Zohran Mamdani holds a substantial lead over his rivals with hours to before polls close at 9pm.

The Democratic candidate saw a record number of New Yorkers cast their ballot for him in early voting, buoyed by a surge of younger supporters.

Mikie Sherrill, the New Jersey gubernatorial candidate, said that bomb threats at polling stations this morning were an attempt to suppress the vote.

Asked about Election Day bomb threats at several New Jersey polling places, which forced some voters to cast their ballots elsewhere, Ms Sherrill said none of them were credible and that voters wouldn't be deterred.

“Obviously this is an attempt to suppress the vote here, and I don't think New Jerseyans take very kindly to that kind of tampering in our election system,” she said.

After casting her ballot alongside her husband, she told voters: “I think I'm going to do quite well today.”

New Jersey is one of the most closely watched local elections taking place today and is widely viewed as a bellweather on the mood of the nation 10 months after Donald Trump's return to office.

Polling data shows Ms Sherrill is leading her opponent Jack Ciattarelli going into election day, but the Republican has narrowed the gap to single digits.

Donald Trump has claimed voter fraud is taking place in California's redistricting ballot.

The president said that the vote is a “giant scam” and that cases of Republicans allegedly being “shut out” from mail-in ballots are under legal review.

“The Unconstitutional Redistricting Vote in California is a GIANT SCAM in that the entire process, in particular the Voting itself, is RIGGED,” Mr Trump wrote on Truth Social. “All ‘Mail-In' Ballots, where the Republicans in that State are ‘Shut Out,' is under very serious legal and criminal review. STAY TUNED!”

Californians go to the polls today in a special election over plans to re-draw the voting map in the Democrats' favour.

The proposal, that could erase as many as five Republican districts, is designed to blunt the effect of similar Republican redistricting efforts in Texas.

Mr Trump has long railed against mail-in ballots, claiming that rampant voter fraud was responsible for his loss in the 2020 presidential election to Joe Biden.

Andrew Cuomo said he plans to make Muslims a “big part” of his administration if he wins the New York mayoral race.

Responding to claims he has stoked Islamophobia against his opponent, Zohran Mamdani, Mr Cuomo said he had met with “members of the Muslim community” and planned to appoint them to senior positions if he lands a surprise victory.

The former New York governor initially said Brian Lehrer had it “all upside down” after the WNYC radio host claimed voters will be furious that he came from behind by playing on what they will see as Islamophobia with attack ads against Mr Mamdani.

“I am all about unifying,” Mr Cuomo said, touting his record as governor.

The independent candidate has been criticised for his failure to condemn unsavoury attacks on his opponent, asking a recent interviewer if he should be expected to “respond to everything that is said”.

The Department of Justice has deployed election monitors to New Jersey and California, stoking controversy.

The DoJ announced last week it would send federal observers to the states following requests from their state GOP officials.

The election monitors will be in six jurisdictions: Passaic County, New Jersey, and Los Angeles, Orange, Kern, Riverside and Fresno counties in California.

Democrats have criticised the move, claiming it could intimidate voters.

Passaic, a key swing county, is one of several regions to be targeted by bomb scares on Tuesday morning, causing some voters to be diverted to other polling stations.

The DoJ said its goal in deploying the monitors was “to ensure transparency, ballot security, and compliance with federal law”.

Zohran Mamdani is banking on his policy of free childcare to win over late-deciding voters as they head to the polls.

Asked which of his policies he wanted late voters to focus on, he pointed to the cost of raising a family in New York.

“Today it costs a family, on average, $22,500 a year to pay for childcare for one child. That is more money than it would cost to send that child 18 years later to CUNY,” the city university system, he told WNYC radio host Brian Lehrer.

Mr Mamdani added that in just one year, the state recently lost $23 billion in economic activity “from families who had to skip shifts to take care of kids or left the state altogether because of how expensive it is to raise that family”.

On election day, the democratic-socialist candidate is leading his main rival, Andrew Cuomo, by double digits, according to most polls, having run a campaign laser focused on the cost of living.

Andrew Cuomo, the former New York governor, cast his ballot at a high school shortly after 10am, talking and shaking hands with people at the polling station.

“I'm feeling very good. I feel the momentum is on our side,” Mr Cuomo said after casting his vote, according to CNN.

“I can tell you this, I voted a lot of times, first time I ever walked into a polling place and the polling place cheered for me. That's a good sign. And the record turnout is a good sign.”

Zohran Mamdani has said he will not be intimidated by Donald Trump if he is elected mayor of New York.

The self-described Democratic socialist said he would not cave to any threats by the president to withhold money from the city if he wins today's election as polls suggest he will.

“I look forward to fighting for every single dollar this city is owed,” Mr Mamdani told reporters on Tuesday morning. “I look forward to utilising every single tool at my disposal as the next mayor of this city to fight for the people of it. That means using the courts. That means using the bully pulpit. That means ensuring that we actually follow the letter of the law.

“But I will not be intimidated by this president,” he said.

Donald Trump has said that any Jew that votes for Zohran Mamdani is a “stupid person” in an incendiary post.

The Democratic mayoral frontrunner is staunchly pro-Palestine and has been highly critical of Israel's military actions in Gaza, which he has labelled as “genocidal”.

The US president wrote on Truth Social: “Any Jewish person that votes for Zohran Mamdani, a proven and self professed JEW HATER, is a stupid person!!!”

Mr Trump has repeatedly attacked Mr Mamdani, branding him a “communist” and threatening to withhold funding if he wins the election as expected.

On Monday, the president gave his backing to Andrew Cuomo, the former Democratic governor of New York now running as an independent.

Mr Mamdani has repeatedly denied accusations of anti-Semitism over his criticism of the Israeli government.

The bomb threats that forced authorities in New Jersey to close some polling stations and secure others were later determined to be unfounded.

Tahesha Way, who serves as the state's top election official, said the threats had been emailed to seven counties, including Passaic, a key swing county.

“Law enforcement has determined that there are no credible threats at this time,” Ms Way said. “We are doing everything in our power to protect voters and poll workers and coordinate closely with state, local and federal partners to ensure a smooth and safe election.”

The threats came as the final day of voting began in the state's closely-watched race for governor and a year after a series of bomb threats disrupted voting during last year's presidential election, mostly in battleground states.

Donald Trump has spent months demonising Zohran Mamdani as a “100 per cent communist lunatic” who would ensure the demise of his home city should he be elected mayor.

So when he was confronted with claims that the political rookie is a “Left-wing version” of himself, he quickly brushed off the comparison.

“Well, I think I'm a much better-looking person than him, right?”, the US president told CBS News. A deft deflection, but one that would not stop people drawing parallels between himself and the rising political star.

Both Mr Mamdani, 34, and Mr Trump, 79, began as political outsiders who defied the odds to beat their establishment career politician rivals to win their party's nomination. They are both charismatic orators who leveraged the power of social media as a tool to connect with voters that feel disillusioned and left behind by the two-party political machine.

Rather than be bogged down by the minutiae of policy, the two men also picked issues that resonated with the reality of people's everyday lives. They plugged pithy campaign slogans on affordability that cut through with voters struggling to pay bills and fuel their cars.

Andrew Cuomo received last-minute endorsements from Donald Trump and Elon Musk on Monday.

The president said he would rather see a “bad Democrat” win than a “communist”, while the Tesla billionaire parodied the mayoral candidate's name as “Mumdumi”.

Zohran Mamdani has attempted to spin the endorsements in his favour, claiming it shows Mr Cuomo represents the status quo.

Another big endorsement for @andrewcuomo. And it only cost $959 million in tax breaks. pic.twitter.com/p5pS3D0v9G

Donald Trump has urged Republicans to end the Senate filibuster, claiming not doing so will allow the Democrats to perform well at next year's mid-term elections. 

He posted on Truth Social: “The Democrats are far more likely to win the Midterms, and the next Presidential Election, if we don't do the Termination of the Filibuster (The Nuclear Option!).”

“If we do terminate the Filibuster, we will get EVERYTHING approved, like no Congress in History.”

The president has repeatedly called for the Senate to take action as the US government shutdown stretches into its second month. 

The filibuster rule mandates that 60 Senate votes are needed to pass most legislation. 

The Republicans hold a majority in the Senate - 53 out of 100 seats - but still need some Democrat votes to push through legislation, including Mr Trump's spending plan. 

“It is now time for the Republicans to play their “Trump card,” and go for what is called the Nuclear Option. Get rid of the filibuster, and get rid of it, now!” the president said on Friday as pressure grows for the shutdown to end. 

New York City could be poised to elect a staunchly socialist, pro-Palestine mayoral candidate who wants to control food prices and almost double the minimum wage.

Zohran Mamdani's improbable ascent to the cusp of leading America's biggest city has sent shock waves through the Democratic Party, which is struggling to decide whether to embrace a centrist or a populist, Leftist path.

The 34-year-old has generated national buzz and comes with a string of endorsements from celebrities and big-name progressives, including Bernie Sanders and Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez.

Born in Uganda, his family moved to New York when he was seven. He is a fierce critic of Israel's war in Gaza, putting him at odds with much of the Democratic establishment, who see him as a potential setback in their effort to broaden the party's national appeal.

Mr Mamdani has promised to raise taxes on the richest New Yorkers and use the money to make city buses free and provide free, universal child care. He has also promised to freeze rent for people living in about 1 million rent-regulated apartments.

As well as becoming New York's most Left-leaning mayor, he would also be the city's first Muslim leader. New York City has not elected a Republican since 2005.

A post shared by Zohran Kwame Mamdani (@zohrankmamdani)

Polls close first in Virginia at 7pm ET (12am GMT), followed by New Jersey at 8pm (1am GMT) and New York at 9pm (2am GMT).

Voter enthusiasm already appears high.

More than 3 million people voted early in Virginia, New York and New Jersey – in each case far exceeding the totals from four years ago.

In New York City, there were 735,000 ballots cast, according to the city elections board, more than four times the number in 2021.

Donald Trump has threatened to withhold funding from New York if Zohran Mamdani is elected as the city's next mayor in Tuesday's election.

The US president has repeatedly derided Mr Mamdani, 34, as a communist, and on Monday gave his backing to Andrew Cuomo, the former Democratic governor of New York now running as an independent.

He posted on Truth Social: “It is highly unlikely that I will be contributing Federal Funds, other than the very minimum as required, to my beloved first home, because of the fact that, as a Communist, this once great City has ZERO chance of success, or even survival!”

He continued: “It can only get worse with a Communist at the helm, and I don't want to send, as President, good money after bad.”

A series of bomb threats have forced polling stations to shut in New Jersey ahead of the elections that will decide the state's new governor and New York City's mayor.

Authorities said at least two sites in Paterson city were shut down after threats were received, while officials are reviewing emails about further threats, some of which have been exposed as hoaxes.

New York has been gripped by one of the most publicised races in its history between Democratic nominee Zohran Mamdani, a 34-year-old democratic socialist, and former Democratic Governor Andrew Cuomo, 67, who is running as an independent.

Mr Mamdani, who has experienced a swift and spectacular rise from a relative unknown, is widely expected to win. He has centred his campaign around the cost of living, giving him a double digit lead in most polls.

Donald Trump last night threatened to withhold funding from New York if Mr Mamdani, who he has frequently branded as a communist, is elected.

The coinciding elections for governor in Virginia and New Jersey will be seen as even more critical gauges of the US political mood nearly 10 months into Mr Trump's return to power.

The New Jersey race has emerged as the most hotly contested campaign, with polls showing Democrat Mikie Sherrill, a congresswoman, holding a narrow lead over her Republican challenger, former state lawmaker Jack Ciattarelli.

We are bringing you all the latest news from the elections in New York, New Jersey and Virginia that will offer an early test of Donald Trump's agenda.

Title: Zohran Mamdani's victory should terrify the Democrats
Description:
The socialist's win in New York will make it far harder for the national party to resist the lure of the far-Left
		

Copy link

twitter

facebook

whatsapp

email

Copy link

twitter

facebook

whatsapp

email

Copy link

twitter

facebook

whatsapp

email

Copy link

twitter

facebook

whatsapp

email

There was no defeat to be snatched from the jaws of victory.

The man who shockingly secured the Democratic nomination in June has un-shockingly won the election. Zohran Mamdani, the dimpled, wise-cracking democratic socialist, will become mayor of New York, America's most populous city.

For those with a taste for 11th-hour upsets in politics, there was little reason to anticipate a surprise. The Mamdani campaign carried the momentum from its primary battle, drawing the highest turnout in a New York mayoral race since the 1960s.

A highly-energised coalition of young white Leftists and new immigrant communities disrupted the traditional New York Dem voting blocs. In the end, it wasn't even remotely close.

It will be hard to resist the urge to see the result as a stunning endorsement of Mamdani's particular flavour of progressivism, bolstered by further blows against the GOP in New Jersey and Virginia.

Trump threw out the Republican Party's po-faced gatekeepers. Mamdani will surely hope to do the same for his own party, paving the way for a popular Leftism that doesn't care about winning over the centre and certainly doesn't care about the deficit.

But this wasn't just an election “won”. It was also brutally “lost”. It's astonishing that, despite his top-dollar funding, Andrew Cuomo felt so dead in the water so quickly. His moderate cred was shredded by the defection of several Obama-era heavyweights.

The voting public, too, seemed to be given the cold shoulder, even as Mamdani zipped around everywhere from mosques to bodegas. And what stunning comms strategy did the Cuomo campaign employ instead? According to Cuomo's social media feed, AI slop videos of Mamdani trick-or-treating.

There was a hint of #NeverTrump about the Cuomo campaign, which started on a delirious note and ended in fits of hysteria. Its failure to enforce basic message discipline (taxes, law and order, housing!) in favour of pearl-clutching hardly suited the public's obvious appetite for radical change on cost of living issues. Cuomo ran as if he were the establishment candidate who had somehow screwed up sorting his credentials – which, in a manner of speaking, he had.

All the attempts to portray Mamdani in a menacing light backfired horribly. His policies might be dangerous. But the man himself was rarely photographed without a goofy smile on his face. Voters just didn't buy it. For those fanatically opposed to Mamdani, it was a deeply frustrating situation.

The case for the Republican candidate Curtis Sliwa to stand aside may have been strong, but demands for him to do so to help out a Left-liberal establishment Democrat who didn't bother to promise anything in return reeked of entitlement. In such circumstances, it was hard to view Trump's extremely belated intervention as anything other than a trollish twisting of the knife.

And why wouldn't the president engage in a little bit of trolling? He has little reason to fear Mamdani and his ilk. Each progressive victory makes it just a little bit more difficult for the Democrat establishment to resist the demands of its hyper-polarised base to shift Left. Sure, a guy like Mamdani can win in New York. But a woman like Kamala Harris can win in California. There's still everything to play for in 2028.

What is clear is that neither party can fight and win without a clear articulation of what their candidate actually intends to do. ou might sputter at slogans like “freeze the rent” just as many before sputtered at “build the wall”, but it's clear that turning out polarised electorates requires a strong policy offering.

Mamdani will have plenty of opportunities now to crash and burn. But when it comes to campaigning, he has raised the game for 2028.

Title: Zohran Mamdani Wins Decisive Victory in NYC, Triumphing Over Billionaire Onslaught
Description:
Mamdani's win is a historic victory for the left over a powerful, moneyed coalition of forces that aimed to defeat him.

Support justice-driven, accurate and transparent news — make a quick donation to Truthout today! 

Democratic socialist Zohran Mamdani won the New York City mayoral race on Tuesday, marking a historic win for the left over a high-powered, moneyed coalition of establishment forces that came together in hopes of defeating him.

The race was called by the Associated Press just 34 minutes after polls closed on Tuesday night, with Mamdani nine points ahead of the next runner up, disgraced former Gov. Andrew Cuomo, with 75 percent of the vote counted. More than 2 million people voted before polls closed on Tuesday night — a level of turnout the city's mayoral election has not seen since 1969. 

Mamdani, slated to be inaugurated on January 1, is one of just a handful of self-proclaimed socialists to win the mayoral election in New York City. He is also the first Muslim person to ever win the seat for the largest city in the U.S. 

Get the news you want, delivered to your inbox every day.

A wide variety of factors contributed to Mamdani's win.

His affordability platform consistently polled well as he made promises to tackle the rising cost of living in one of the most expensive cities in the U.S. At a time when other politicians embraced the establishment's predominantly pro-Israel political stance, Mamdani carved out an anti-genocide, pro-human rights position more in line with popular American opinion on the issue.

His team's savvy social media strategy was notable, highlighting Mamdani's strengths as a charismatic speaker as well as his simple, repeatable policy proposals. He also received the backing of some of the country's most popular politicians, like fellow democratic socialists Sen. Bernie Sanders (I-Vermont) and Rep. Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez (D-New York).

But the success of the Mamdani campaign went far beyond what traditional campaign metrics typically measure. In fact, a traditional campaign likely couldn't achieve the things the Mamdani campaign did — like go from polling at 1 percent in February to pulling out a significant win against an established politician, much less scoring such a victory while billionaires, Republicans, and plenty of mainstream Democrats banded against him.

To the contrary, analysts have noted that a major facet of Mamdani's appeal is his bucking of the establishment. During the campaign, he rejected Democrats' tried-and-failed methods of electioneering, tacking to the left on issues like trans rights and Palestine, at a time when the party's popularity is dropping lower than ever. Mamdani's platform mobilized a huge number of supporters, with the campaign saying it surpassed 3 million doors knocked by Election Day. 

All the while, the Mamdani campaign weathered attacks from all angles — including persistent racism and Islamophobia leveraged against him from Democrats and Republicans alike. 

Major outlets from the New York Post to The New York Times ran hit pieces on subjects like his racial identity and, countless times, his stance on Palestinian and human rights. The Trump administration, including the president himself, threw its weight behind Cuomo, and congressional Republicans are pushing to deport him. Democratic leaders — including New York's own Senate Minority Leader Chuck Schumer — broke with party tradition and refused to endorse him. Billionaires and other deep-pocketed donors gave $40 million to pro-Cuomo, anti-Mamdani super PACs.

Mamdani confronted these challenges head on, often in ways that subverted typical campaign practices. When Cuomo was endorsed by Trump, his campaign touted it in a tongue-in-cheek post on social media, saying, “Congratulations, @AndrewCuomo. I know how hard you worked for this.” 

As Cuomo levied Islamophobic attacks against Mamdani in the final weeks of the campaign, Mamdani embraced his identity. He directly addressed Muslim New Yorkers in the wake of hateful rhetoric from his competitors and current Mayor Eric Adams, noting that he pledged to fight for the safety and security of all New Yorkers. Many Muslims said that these words spoke deeply to the community, which has faced violent hatred, especially after 9/11. 

“The dream of every Muslim is simply to be treated the same as any other New Yorker,” Mamdani said. “And yet, for too long, we have been told to ask for less than that and to be satisfied with whatever little we receive. No more.”

As Trump cracks down on political speech, independent media is increasingly necessary.

Sharon Zhang is a news writer at Truthout covering politics, climate and labor. Before coming to Truthout, Sharon had written stories for Pacific Standard, The New Republic, and more. She has a master's degree in environmental studies. She can be found on Twitter and Bluesky.

Title: Trump Admin Signals It May Not Pay Furloughed Workers After Shutdown Ends
Description:
A 2019 statute signed into law by Trump himself requires furloughed workers to be compensated when shutdowns end.

Truthout is an indispensable resource for activists, movement leaders and workers everywhere. Please make this work possible with a quick donation.

A new message to federal workers sent from several government agencies suggests that the Trump administration may not give back pay to furloughed workers once the shutdown ends, violating a statute that President Donald Trump himself signed into law six years ago.

The message doesn't explicitly state that furloughed employees — those who have been told to stop working during the federal shutdown but will return to work once it ends — will not receive missed paychecks. However, it omits them when discussing how excepted employees (those currently working without pay) will be compensated.

“Once an appropriation or continuing resolution is enacted, excepted employees are entitled to receive payment,” a sentence in the message reads.

The message does not offer furloughed employees the same assurance. 

A similar message was sent to employees in October. According to federal workers from several agencies who received that message, it did not include the sentence regarding how excepted employees in particular would be paid. 

Federal law “provides that employees shall be paid for the period of the lapse in appropriations ends,” the message sent to employees in early October stated. “As soon as possible after the appropriations lapse ends, you will be paid for the period of the lapse in appropriations.”

That part of October's message, which doesn't differentiate between furloughed and excepted employees, was not included in November's message.

At least 670,000 federal staffers have been furloughed since the start of the shutdown, which began on October 1. As of Tuesday night, the shutdown is now the longest in U.S. history, with no compromise between Democrats and Republicans on a continuing resolution in sight. 

The message to federal employees is the latest indication that furloughed workers will not get back pay. Earlier in October, a leaked draft of a White House memo argued that workers may not receive those payments if they're not specifically included in a continuing resolution bill. Republican leaders, like Speaker of the House Mike Johnson, have continually pressed Democrats in the Senate to pass a continuing resolution that was passed in the House before the shutdown began, which would mean those payments wouldn't be included in the legislation's language. 

Failing to pay workers their missed wages would be a violation of the Government Employee Fair Treatment Act (GEFTA), which states that furloughed workers “shall be paid” compensation that would have been owed to them had the shutdown not occurred. 

While the Trump White House is signaling that it may attempt to withhold these payments, it was Trump himself who signed GEFTA into law, in 2019 during the last government shutdown.

“The law is the law. That legislation was signed into law — and there is nothing this administration can do to change that,” Sen. Chris Van Hollen (D-Maryland) said in reaction to reporting on the draft memo in early October.

Truthout is funded almost entirely by readers — that's why we can speak truth to power and cut against the mainstream narrative. But independent journalists at Truthout face mounting political repression under Trump.

Focusing on both national and local topics since the early 2000s, he has produced thousands of articles analyzing the issues of the day and their impact on the American people. He can be found on most social media platforms under the handle @thatchriswalker.
